Slicing through foes while whistling a tune PvM/E (1-40) and PvP

Dragonborn Ranger (Striker), Ranger26, Bard4, RDD10
By Tyr Templar
Author’s Note: This build, Dragonborn Ranger (Striker) is adapted from a character originally developed for NWN2/ECB, entitled: The Sentinel (Dragon Scout) ranger 11 / bard 1 / red dragon disciple 4 / divine champion 4, which made its debut in the ECB in March, 2007 (NWN2-First 20), forming part of my Dragon Blade series as adapted from a series of the same name developed for NWN1/ECB. Dragonborn Ranger is a dual-wielding dragon blade, the rest of the series being comprised of Fighter/RDD and Barbarian/RDDs, which series explores synergies as such of the melee classes with RDD.
Concept: Dragon Blades were an elite fighting force, comprised of combat warriors who actually rode and fought upon dragons; the pair, rider and dragon, were dedicated to the preservation and defense of a far-away land, which few if any mortals from middle-earth have ever been known to visit. It is said the bond between dragon and his/her rider is a strong and magical one. It is also said that, in time, the bond between a rider and his/her dragon grows, such that they begin to “see” and “think” as one, with the one eventually taking on characteristics of the other. It is widely believed all Dragon Blades (and their dragons) died out during the time of the dragon wars.

They are wrong: a few survived.

Pros and Cons:
Dual Wield, fully Bane-Charged (which comes on nice and early, too), high RDD STR with a high/PG Naked AB 50, +1 Song: 51 (55 self-buffed, -2 dual), and a double weapon focus for the delivery of different damage types. Decent AC, especially for STR-based, dual wielder (better AC in light leather dual wielding than enjoys “good warrior” in full plate with tower, there being room in light leather for even more AC from DEX (unlike plate), with Striker able to put on the big board for even more, too, thus a really decent AC for a dual wield melee especially, thanks of course to bard and RDD). As if not more importantly, enjoys over 500 HPs (534 in fact, such that Striker ain’t exactly afraid of a little heat); this, even although with this AB/damage, heh, dead don't strike back, eh? (Still nice to have on a dual-wielder, in combination with over 500HPs as here, such that defense has not been overlooked).

Also has a really decent skillset, especially nice for a melee, including (your choice) deadly traps or UMD, enjoying the good (non-dispellable) Ranger book along with a useful pet (bear or panther), too. While there’s no such thing as too much saves, saves are really quite decent across the board, bolstered by Ranger spells and RDD immunities [i.e. has a really nice fort, but not so much will, and which you’ll shore up via clarity potions as is rather typical of melee builds).

Combo makes for a very strong melee, a level 40 build that is playable/versatile, too. And proof positive once and for all that bane-charged, strength-based Ranger’s nothing short of a deadly lethal melee combatant (especially when bolstered by RDD as here!); slices through foes like there's no tomorow while whistling a tune, with great looking dragon wings, too (which wings just happen to be red, so just in time for X-Mas!). With 7 FEs, that be good and plenty (and then some, especially with all that high/PG RDD STR, dual wield apr, etc. and all!). That said, in terms of high magic worlds where lots of things have DR and/or elemental resistances, not only will you enjoy your bane-charged, high STR, dual apr damage of course, but also the ability to dish different physical damage types, too, most true. Dual enabling not only the delivery of different physical damage types but also different elemental enhancements and at the same time as well. Like having say fire and acid on one set, cold and electricity on another, thus covering everything off and regardless and which is yet another great thing about dual when it comes to high magic settings especially (arcane access and traps which come in different flavors, damage types etc. are nice, too). Of course, heh, dev.crit is definitely a (very) effective option as well, for sure, and either way wave bye bye to your foe.... (wonderful to hear, Lines, my pleasure, and enjoy!!).

Yep, what's not to love about epic, bane charged Ranger? Best, consistent damage in the entire game, especially when bolstered by RDD as here (just don't get any better really). Then, been telling you guys for years that Rangers are nothing short of awesome, this build being proof-positive of same! (thanks, guys).

Theoretical Stats and Ability Caps, etc.
@Zork: appreciate the question, and understand completely what you are saying/asking. Having returned to NWN1 (my first love!) after spending much time NWN2 side (asked to help out, which I did), I am thoroughly re-testing everything NWN1 on account of 1.69. In terms of NWN2, it's important to note many changes in terms of that game (in line with PnP) found its way into NWN1 via 1.69 (and where --NWN2--ability stats are capped, hard-coded); I assumed on account of a bunch of other stuff I read (and which I subsequently found through testing to be correct) that what others said about it was likewise correct but turns out that, while they were right about other stuff on this they are not. (Yep. Serves me right, I suppose, and which I just tested and in the OC proper!). Very sorry about that (and I'll edit the build note, accordingly).

In terms of how it works, as I understood it PRE-PATCH, ability stats are "capped" at some theoretical number, theoretical because they're not actually obtainable (as in never); this, on account of not only the max +12 ability stat cap via magic, items, but also the character creation limitation itself--namely, the max level 40 character cap (PrC and Custom Content excepted). And yes, in terms of abilities then what you say hypothetically would be correct since ability stats a character actually "Owns" (as in natural ability stats from character creation stats and ability score increases, feats, racial boni, RDD boni) are just that, and which natural stats you can enhance to a max +12 via spells, items.

Apologize for any and all confusion, and thanks so much again everyone for your kind words, comments and praises.

No, that hasn't changed, Mick. Used the term "full strength" loosely--as a pun of sorts--when it comes to the Epic Ranger's FE/BoE as cf. STR rules; i.e., unlike STR mod, the epic ranger's FE/BoE applies in full on main hand and off hand both, thus a double bang for your BoE/FE buck so to speak most true (well, more really, dual wield apr and all!). And yes, this is unlike the STR mod, as you say and as is documented in the build itself. (And good to be clear about all this, I agree, for the benefit of new members/players and on account of 1.69 and uh some "confusion" out there about it).

STR mod and damage--how it works:
In brief, STR mod is applied differently depending on actual class of weapon wielded. Namely: x1 STR MOD (or, "full STR" if you will) on single wielded weapon (i.e., sword+board), x1.5 large 2-hander (like heavy flail, great sword, etc.) and, in the case of dual wield, its x1 on main hand, x 1/2 on the off, yes, and regardless whether wielding 2 weapons (like two kukri, bastard sword and kukri, maces, etc.) -OR- large double-bladed/2-handed exotic like dire mace, two-bladed sword or double-axe, as set out in the build. Only the off-hand weapon matters for being light. The main hand weapon just has to be small enough that you can use it with one hand to allow the off-hand slot a weapon (double weapons are an exception to this rule). The penalty for dual-wield is -6 to main hand attacks, -10 to off hand attacks, but feats and the off-hand weapon choice can make up for this providing the following bonuses:

Ambidexterity: +4 to off-hand attacks
Two weapon fighting: +2 to main hand attacks, +2 to off-hand attacks
Dual wield: Same as ambidexterity and two weapon fighting (so long as you have light armor or less), does not stack with either ambidexterity or two-weapon fighting.
Light off-hand: +2 to main hand attacks, +2 to off-hand attacks, if the off-hand weapon is at least one size less than your creature size or you are using a two sided weapon
Improved two weapon fighting: one extra attack in the off-hand progression

So here are the changes I made:

1. I adjusted starting dex to 10 and constitution to 12. Imho, +1AC is better than +1HP/level. This build already has a decent number of overall hitpoints so losing 1 per level is acceptable imo. Now why dex 10? The numbers line up much better in every case:
  • In early levels, chainmail/breastplate AC can be maxed with (self-cast) Cat's Grace (total AC bonus = +7, assuming a Cat's Grace roll of 4 or 5). Of course, we would like to dual-wield from level 1, but with this starting dex score, any challenging environment will demand chainmail + tower shield.
  • In mid levels (assuming +4 dex gear or better), you can get the same AC with studded leather and self-cast Cat's Grace (total AC bonus = +7, assuming a Cat's Grace roll of 4 or 5). Once you transition to light armor, you can freely switch between dual-wielding and weapon-and-shield.
  • Now, in higher levels, when UMD gear, ioun stones and other goodies come into play, it's feasible to have dex capped at 22, giving +6 dex AC. That will allow for +8 total AC with leather armor. Ranger-specific armor is almost always leather, studded leather or hide. If you want to wear a nice suit of leather armor, you'll want to be able to maximize your dex AC.
  • If you start with 8 dex, you'll always fall a bit short. In early levels, you'll be able to get up to 13 dex via Cat's Grace for only +6 total AC when wearing chainmail/breastplate. In higher levels, if you manage to fully buff your dex to 20, it will be awkward because both studded leather and regular leather will only give +7 total AC. Remember that you might want to wear a nice suit of enchanted leather armor (perhaps one that bestows Haste for example) but you'll never be able to maximize your AC because of the NWN +12 cap. I guess it won't matter if you're going to wear studded leather anyway, but I would like to have the option to "upgrade" if I'm able to cap my dex.
  • Finally, dex doesn't only affect armor - every time you use a missile weapon, you get +1 AB thanks to the higher starting dex score.
2. I adjusted epic feats to get +2 strength at the cost of two favored enemy types. +2 strength means +1 Dev Crit DC vs. non-crit-immunes and +1 AB +1 damage vs. all enemies. The cost is fewer enemy types that can be threatened by Bane of Enemies and the bonus damage to favored enemies (+7 damage at ranger level 25). However, remember that this is a Dev Crit build so any enemy that's vulnerable to critical hits can potentially die every time you attack it (assuming your AB is high enough, which is another reason AB should be buffed). Moreover, the two final favored enemies in the build are taken at levels 38 & 40 so it's really an environment-based decision at that point. If you really need an extra favored enemy type for the module or persistent world you're in, then you can cut epic prowess to add one or if you really need all seven, then you can use Tyr Templar's feat plan. I realize that if you're building for PvP, you'll probably want to have all the player races as favored enemies so you might need all seven in that case (human, elf, dwarf, gnome, halfling, half-orc, half-elf). However, my build is for PvM.
3. Tiny note about Animal Empathy: it's my personal preference to have that skill available to use. In many modules, rangers and druids get special dialogue options, etc, just by having even one point invested. It's one of those skills that you can only use if you are trained in it so that one point can really go a long way. Many modules have animals running around that can be used as companions before you have any summon creature spells or your animal companion. Moreover, as experienced players will be well aware, the skill can be easily "buffed" via equipment or potions to beat skill checks if needed. A lot of ranger-specific gear includes bonuses to this skill but you still can't use it if you don't invest at least one point. Of course, for anyone who is not interested in using the skill, they may adjust skills so they end up with one more point in Listen at level 40.

As a side-note, I don't really understand the concept of this website. There are many builds listed as "epic" builds. This build is in the full level 40 section. But I'm told that the AC isn't high enough on it. My problem is, "Where can I find the good builds?" As a relatively inexperienced player, I don't know how to tell if a build is good or not. I rely on this website's listings and the WoG website's listings yet I'm told that one of the builds listed here is not good enough. If it's not good enough, then why is it listed here in the first place? And if it's not good enough, then where can I find the builds that are good enough?
This is actually a good question (or questions), so I will try to answer them as best I can.

An Epic Build means exactly that - a build that is Epic.  Meaning it is of Epic Level.  This in and of itself does not mean that it is a "good" build.  Some builds are...well, experiments in what is possible, or how to get the highest AB, AC, or [insert desired goal here]. They demonstrate what is POSSIBLE. Good builders are demonstrating what is possible.  Not all are like this, of course.


Others are good, solid builds that are playable from level 1 to 40.  And still others mature at late levels (sometimes at level 40).

For a good, solid build one should really first get acquainted with the ins-and-outs of NWN.  What exactly is a good AB to have?  How about AC?  What sort of damage should be dealt out? And so on.

Now, you may be asking (or thinking) "how come this info is not already posted, or certain builds exclaimed as "the best"?

And the answer to that is actually pretty simple : because it depends on the environment where one plays in.  Magic level, opponents AB, AC, DR, Regen, Abilities, etc.  Items that are available, Feats that are nerfed, or changed and a whole lot of other factors that need to be weighted and considered.

This is why you see a lot of "naked" references to both AC and AB in most builds posted here.

Another factor to consider when discussing environment is the AI (or real people in the case of PvP).  Bioware AI is generally "dumb" - it doesn't make good use of most abilities, etc.  There are custom AIs that have been created by the Community to compensate for this (and of course Bioware AI can be modified and made better by using may of the inactive parts).  Another factor is how the encounters are designed, numbers, what is normal for a "m0b", a sub-boss, and a boss encounter, and of course spells and abilities that are allowed and used.

Now, if you are planning on only using builds for the OCs, and most Mods in SP, things will most likely be easy going.  Aieland Saga and Swordflight are supposed to be harder, I have heard (I personally have not played them - I spend most of my time these days on PWs).  I rather suspect that your chosen build in this thread will do very well in SoU.  SoU is very easy.

I will give you an example of some things on WoG that one encounters - let us take a Drow Warrior for example.  It uses a Katana (magical), has Plate Mail +5, a Tower Shield + 5, and good, solid AC, +49 AB (Weapon Master levels), likes to use Ki Strikes for max damage, and likes to crit ALOT (I've seen crits do up to 100+ damage per hit).  These things are put together with some Rogue Crossbow users who sneak attack and some Sorcerer Mages that like to throw around epic spells, etc.  One can run into these gents at relatively low epic levels.  They of course also have the famous Drow Magic Resistence (as well as having DR vs slashing and piercing).

Or we can consider our friend, Goristo.  He's a demon, and he is really, really nasty.  Likes to sneak about, and can really put the hurt on anyone!  A high AB of +45, does a brickload of damage per hit, has high DR, and high AC, and is generally just a nasty customer.  One can run into these under epic level (aroundabout).

Now, the thing about these critters is that they all have massive amounts of hit points, and very high Fort saves.  This means that most Dev Crits are going to be "fishing" for 1s (meaning trying to get them to roll a 1 for a save, which auto-fails).  To that is the high AC, meaning that it could be that it is impossible to Dev Crit them because one cannot confirm the Crit roll vs that AC (meaning one needs a natural 20 to hit).

So this is where AB and AC come into the picture (we'll leave DR and Regen out here).  To start getting relatively good numbers for the Dev Crit DC, one needs a high Str here (The difficulty class of the save is 10 + ½ character level + strength modifier).  So we are looking at 10+20 (max level modifier)+Str modifier as the DC.  And the above fiends have Forts that approach or exceed 50.  So one can start to see that things are not just "cut and dried" because one has AB X or AC Y or Ability Z.

And for our example (Dev Crit), we need to threaten it.  That means we need to hit, first.  If the AC is high enough (and our AB is not), then there will never be a Dev Crit threatened, because we need a natural 20 just to hit!  That means that the Crit itself (that threatens a Dev Crit save) will never be confirmed, because the natural 20 rule does not apply to crit confirming.  So even though in your example one has a Kukri (which has a really good crit range) and let us say is Keen (which increases the Crit Range) and of course the build has Improved Critical (to improve the range even further), it will not matter if the roll needed to hit is far above the crit range!

This also applies to your opponent(s) - because they have the same "rules" and must obey them, for the most part.  And this is why I mentioned that your build has low AC.  This does not mean that in the environment where you are planning on using it (if I understand correctly it is going to be SoU) that this is true.  But in the environment where I play, it is.

And it is exactly for these reasons that we do not have a "best builds" catagory - because the environment has huge deciding factors that determine this.

What can be said is "this AB is good" when compared naked, or "this AC is good" when compared naked, and vice versa.  So it is important to learn where exactly the limits are, naked, for these values.  And by that, I mean not the maximum (because most "max" builds suffer from weaknesses caused by maxing one of these values).  So any build that can sport an AB of 50+ (naked), and a high AC (naked), is going to be something to contend with, most of the time (there are even exceptions to this, as there could be excessive DR, etc that one needs to consider).

AC is even more complicated, because there are ways to "lose" massive amounts of it and it is situational. Trying to "shore" AC up is one of the major concerns and puzzle pieces one has when creating a build.  And there are many ways to do this (just as there are many ways to screw it up!)

So let us talk about a certain build for a moment.  This is one that will often come up I believe, because it is a pretty good build imo - and it is Bard/BG/RDD.  It is, simply put, a monster.  With the Bard Song, Curse Song, Taunt, and Divine Shield (as well as Divine Might) abilities, it totally wrecks stuff.  Built properly in an environment, it will inevitably do well. It really only "suffers" (if that can even be said) from lack of safety from spells (though the saves are exceptionable).  With UMD and access to Spell Mantles, etc, it is pretty much covered, even there.  It is one of those "this build covers all the angles" sort of build.  It is not invincible, mind you, but comes pretty close.

Anyway, I hope I have answered your questions satisfactorily.
